resources.string:
‚≠ï The NOT gate, also known as an inverter, is a digital logic gate that produces an output that is the inverse of its input. 
‚≠ï It has only one input and one output. 
‚≠ï When the input is LOW (0), the output is HIGH (1), and vice versa. 
‚≠ï It is represented by the symbol \( \overline{A} \) or \( A' \).

‚≠ï The AND gate is a digital logic gate that implements logical conjunction. \n‚≠ï It behaves according to the truth table where the output is true only when both inputs are true. \n‚≠ï It can be represented using the symbol \(&\).

‚≠ï The OR gate is a digital logic gate that performs a logical OR operation. \n‚≠ï It has two or more inputs and one output. \n‚≠ï The output of an OR gate is true if any of its inputs are true. Otherwise, the output is false.

‚≠ï The XOR gate (exclusive OR gate) is a digital logic gate that outputs true (1) only when the number of true inputs is odd. \n‚≠ï It behaves according to the truth table: \n‚≠ï The XOR gate is commonly used in various digital circuits, including adders, subtractors, and more.
üìñ This app is designed to help ninth grade students in technology learn about logic gates and their operations. It provides interactive simulations and quizzes to reinforce learning.
